bibl.title: Letter from Lunsford D. Fricks to Henry Rose Carter, April 15, 1921

div1.p: Fricks needs to discuss a malaria control program with Carter and encloses a plan for the examination of school children.

div1.head: Letter from Lunsford D. Fricks to Henry Rose Carter, April 15, 1921
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF
MALARIA INVESTIGATIONS
JC
F.I. - Malaria
Room 17 Court House
Country-wide
M. Con.
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
MEMPHIS, TENN.
April 15, 1921.
Asst. Surgeon-General H. R. Carter,
U. S. Public Health Service,
The Lonsdale - Apt. 206
Washington, D. C.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I am delighted to hear from Dr. Jno. A. Ferrell today
that you are back in the United States. I have a thousand
and one malaria problems which I want to discuss with you
at the earliest convenient date. I can come on to Washington
or would be delighted to have you come and spend a few days
with me at Memphis, whichever is most convenient to you.

I am particularly anxious to have your opinion concern-
ing the enclosed program for county-wide malaria control, or
rather for assistance which the Service can give to well-
organized county health departments in this matter. I dis-
cussed it with Dr. William and Dr. Draper in Virginia, and
Dr. Rankin and Dr. K. E. Miller in North Carolina, and had
hoped that we would be able to put the program in effect in
two or three selected counties in these two states before
now, but it appears that Dr. Griffitts has not yet visitied
North Carolina.

Also, let me know what you think about the plan for the
examination of 50,000 school children which is enclosed
herewith, and whether we might expect to secure any informa-
tion of value from such an examination.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, L. D. Fricks, Surgeon.
Medical Officer in Charge.
